verses.text: Hear this, all you peoples; give ear, all residents of the world,
verses.comment: The psalm opens with a universal summons, addressing all humanity. This sets the tone for a wisdom psalm that instructs beyond Israel alone, inviting all to reflect on mortality and true wealth.

verses.text: both low and high, rich and poor together.
verses.comment: This democratic call underlines that the psalm’s message about wealth, death, and wisdom applies to all social classes. This echoes scriptural teaching on the equal dignity of all before God, a theme deeply rooted in Church tradition.

verses.text: My mouth will speak wisdom; the meditation of my heart will be understanding.
verses.comment: The psalmist assumes the role of a sage, offering divinely inspired wisdom. In the Catholic tradition, wisdom is often personified, pointing to the fullness of revelation in Christ and His Church (see Wisdom 7:25–26).

verses.text: I will incline my ear to a proverb; I will unfold my riddle with the lyre.
verses.comment: ‘Proverb’ and ‘riddle’ indicate that the psalm teaches through wisdom literature’s veiled sayings, much like Christ's parables. The lyre’s mention shows worship (liturgy) as the context for teaching, prefiguring Christian liturgical instruction.

verses.text: Why should I fear in days of trouble, when iniquity surrounds me at my heels?
verses.comment: The psalmist expresses trust in God’s sovereignty over life and death, even amid oppression. A timeless encouragement for Christians in every era to trust in God's providence.

verses.text: those who trust in their wealth and boast in the abundance of their riches?
verses.comment: Here worldly wealth is critiqued. Consistent with both Protestant and Catholic teachings, salvation is not found in material wealth, but implicitly opens a theme on detachment, which the saints and Church Fathers emphasize.

verses.text: No man can by any means redeem another, nor give to God a ransom for him—
verses.comment: Human power is insufficient for redemption; only God can save. A hint pointing forward to Christ’s unique atoning work, later fulfilled in the New Testament (Heb. 9:12).

verses.text: for the redemption of their soul is costly, and never can the price suffice—
verses.comment: The verse teaches that the ransom for a soul is beyond human wealth, foreshadowing the necessity of an infinite Redeemer. Catholics see here a prophetic prefigurement of Christ’s sacrifice and the treasury of grace in the Church.

verses.text: so that he should live forever and never see the pit.
verses.comment: Eternal life is unattainable by human effort. This points to the hope of resurrection, which is fulfilled in Christ. ‘Never see the pit’ (Sheol) evokes traditional teaching on the afterlife and purgation.

verses.text: For he sees that wise men die; likewise the fool and the senseless perish, leaving their wealth to others.
verses.comment: Death is the great equalizer; neither wisdom nor folly can stop it. Catholic tradition encourages preparation for death and judgment, emphasizing the fleeting nature of earthly riches.

verses.text: Their graves are their homes forever, their dwelling places to all generations, though they called lands after their own names.
verses.comment: Earthly power and legacy, such as naming lands, are ultimately futile. The Catholic understanding of temporal vs. eternal things is reinforced here, quietly prompting reflection on the Communion of Saints, whose true home is heaven.

verses.text: Man in his pomp will not remain; he is like the beasts that perish.
verses.comment: All human glory fades. This mirrors the ‘memento mori’ tradition, reminding all Christians to live in light of eternity.

verses.text: This is the destiny of those who are confident in themselves, and of those who approve their words. Selah.
verses.comment: Self-confidence apart from God leads to death. ‘Selah’ prompts meditation; in Catholic liturgy, such pauses are moments for contemplation of eternal truths.

verses.text: Like sheep they are appointed for Sheol; death shall be their shepherd; straight to the grave they descend, and their form shall waste away; Sheol shall be their home.
verses.comment: Death as shepherd is a reversal of Psalm 23’s ‘the Lord is my shepherd.’ Christ’s resurrection transforms death’s power, as taught by the Church. Also subtly highlights the Catholic belief in Christ as the Good Shepherd who saves from death.

verses.text: But God will ransom my soul from the power of Sheol, for he will take me. Selah.
verses.comment: The psalm contrasts human impotence with God’s saving power. ‘He will take me’ prefigures Enoch (Gen. 5:24) and Elijah, but also prefigures the Church’s teaching on corporeal resurrection and the hope of eternal life through Christ.

verses.text: Do not be afraid when a man becomes rich, when the glory of his house increases.
verses.comment: Worldly success is fleeting. The wisdom here echoes Christ’s warnings on riches. Catholic theology emphasizes detachment and trust in God, echoed throughout the psalms.

verses.text: For when he dies he will carry nothing away; his glory will not descend after him.
verses.comment: A direct teaching on the folly of storing up earthly treasures, in line with Catholic saints’ teachings. Points subtly to the value of spiritual riches (see Matt. 6:20).

verses.text: Though in his lifetime he congratulates himself, and men praise you when you do well for yourself,
verses.comment: Worldly acclaim is fleeting and cannot secure eternal destiny. This fits with the Church’s teaching that glory is found in humility and self-sacrifice.

verses.text: he shall go to the generation of his fathers; they shall never again see light.
verses.comment: ‘Never again see light’ suggests exclusion from the beatific vision, a key theme in Catholic teaching on heaven and hell. Darkness is spiritual as well as physical.

verses.text: Man in his pomp, yet without understanding, is like the beasts that perish.
verses.comment: The psalm concludes with the fundamental need for divine wisdom. The Catholic tradition’s emphasis on grace perfecting nature—and the role of the Church in teaching true wisdom—is quietly underscored.
